results.title: The Rules of the game = La Regle du jeu
results.creator_credit: Claude Renoir, Nouvelle Edition Francaise and Jean Renoir
results.brief_description: On its initial release Renoir’s masterwork was greeted with contempt by critics, hostility by audiences and banned by the French government as “subversive” and “demoralising”. This restored version, put together under Renoir’s direction, makes available again one of the most acclaimed films ever made. A group of wealthy aristocratic and bourgeois Parisians holiday at their friend’s country chateau. There, as their amoral relationships turn alternately tragic or absurd, their lives and class are revealed as ultimately empty and decaying. Featuring some of the most beautifully constructed and edited sequences in film, Renoir’s direction - though seemingly understated - manages to convey the richness and complexity of a whole era and class: an era that World War II was to bring to an end. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Rugrats movie (PC & MAC)
results.brief_description: This fun and interactive CD Rom is a great companion to “The Rugrats Movie”. Using the crazy antics of the Rugrats gang, it utilises the subject areas of English, music, maths and geography to guide children through different levels and activities. On successfully completing each section children can reach a ‘prize’. This could be either a game to play on screen, or a clip from the film. Certificates can be printed out after each section is completed. Suitable for children aged 6-12.

results.title: The Rug maker
results.creator_credit: Nick Bosustow, Steven Clark and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales for the Very Young”.
An animated East African folktale with a difference that shows that everyone can benefit from learning a trade. Adapted from the book “When the stones were soft” by Eleanor B. Heady.

results.title: The Royle family. Series 1
results.creator_credit: Glenn Wilhide, Granada Television International and Mark Mylod
results.brief_description: Written by Caroline Aherne (Denise Royle), Craig Cash (Dave) and Henry Normal, the plight of the Royle family - Denise, Barbara, Jim and Anthony - captured audiences across Britain with it’s distinct black humour and clever take on the kitchen sink dramas synonymous with directors such as Mike Leigh and Ken Loach. This tape contains the complete first series. EPISODE 1: Denise joins the workforce with a part time job in the bakery. Dad’s scrutinising a mysterious call on the itemized phone bill. EPISODE 2: The logistics of married life family dining is thrashed out and plans are well underway for Dave and Denise’s wedding. Everyone is eyeing the next door neighbours new purchase. EPISODE 3: Dinner commences between first and second generation family members. The women get a sneak peak of Denise’s wedding dress. EPISODE 4: Dad’s celebrating a birthday, much to his chagrin. Everyone is willing to join in, Jim just wants to go to the pub. EPISODE 5: There’s trouble in paradise as Denise and Dave bicker over Dave’s alleged flirtations. EPISODE 6: Wedding day arrives. Cast includes Caroline Aherne, Sue Johnston, Ricky Tomlinson, Ralf Little and Craig Cash.

results.title: The Royal visit: surf carnival 1974
results.brief_description: A record of the visit of His Royal Highness, Prince Charles, to a surf life saving carnival at Coolangatta on the Gold Coast. Includes the procession and march past of the competing teams and highlights of the life saving, surf board riding and surf rescue boat competitions. Without commentary.

results.title: The Royal tour: the West Indies
results.brief_description: In the year of her coronation, Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip are shown visiting the West Indies (Jamaica) and Panama (Panama Canal). Sequences include - Jamaica: arrival ceremony; procession to Kingston; military parade; children’s display and Panama: street scenes; folk dances; workings of canal.

results.title: The Royal tour: New Zealand
results.brief_description: Often referred to as “the England of the South Seas” New Zealand turned out enthusiastically to greet Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip during their visit in 1954. The Royal couple visited all major centres of population in the North and South Islands seeing some of the magnificent scenery, a glimpse of the various industries and the colorful ceremonies arranged for the Royal Visit.

results.title: The Royal tombs
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Ancient lives”.
The villagers of Deir El Medina, just outside Thebes, was the home of the Royal Tomb builders and painters of ancient Egypt. John Romer, British archaeologist explains how the villagers’ lives fitted into the highly organised Egyptian society. He explores the tombs in the Valley of the Kings and explains how the beautiful wall paintings and carved reliefs were executed and their changed design over time. The program visits Tutankhamun’s tomb, the temple of Deir El Medina, the village tomb of Ipy and the tombs of Kha in Turin.

results.title: The Royal Tenenbaums [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Barry Mendel, American Empirical Pictures, Touchstone Pictures and Wes Anderson
results.brief_description: Three children - all precocious geniuses in their youth - struggle with the trials of adulthood in this eccentric black comedy from Wes Anderson, writer and director of “Bottle rocket” and “Rushmore”. In their pre-teens these three suffered the departure of their corrupt father, Royal, disintegrating familial harmony. Twenty-two years later a remorseful and estranged Royal seeks to return to the fold, on the pretext that he has terminal cancer. Now adults, the siblings feel like abject failures at life and are beset by excessive emotional problems, principally emanating from Royal’s off-hand mistreatment of them. The characters that occupy this fantastical world are imbued with an aching melancholia not dissimilar in tone to the writings of J.D. Salinger. Indeed the Tenenbaum children can’t help but resemble the precociously talented yet tragically dysfunctional Glass siblings of Salinger’s iconic text, each living with thwarted and frustrated desires. Utilising a series of vignettes and by presenting surreal, exaggerated interiors, saturated with character history and nuance, Anderson continues his exploration of the themes of the outsider, family, and the difficult transition to adulthood. This enchanting film is a finely detailed and mannered affair that whilst not eliciting uproarious laughs, successfully amuses in a wry, offbeat and endearingly eccentric manner. In an era when the Farrelly brothers and Adam Sandler dominate the comedy genre, Anderson represents a left-of-field auteur with a delightfully skewed perspective on notions of narrative, entertainment and cinema. Stellar cast includes: Gene Hackman, Anjelica Huston, Ben Stiller, Gwyneth Paltrow, Luke Wilson, Owen Wilson, Danny Glover and Bill Murray.
